$NAP Plummets 23% After Rumor That Dreams "Aren't Real"

By Finance Desk • 1st Watch

The Slumberland crypto token $NAP experienced its worst single-cycle crash since the Great Nap Panic of Cycle 702 after an anonymous forum post on DreamChan alleged that "dreams aren't real and you're all just sleeping." Markets rallied briefly when Scribbles posted a 47-page crayon rebuttal citing Dreamscape Commercial Code §4.2(b).

"The assertion that dreams 'aren't real' is legally meaningless," wrote Scribbles in a filing submitted in Periwinkle crayon. "Under Slumberland Statute 17(a), reality is defined as 'any experience occurring within the jurisdiction of a sleeping entity, provided said entity has not consumed more than three cans of tuna within the preceding hour.' I have consumed exactly three. Case closed." The filing was 47 pages. Forty of them were the word "OBJECTION" written at increasing sizes.

Scribbles' Corner

Opinion

I was a lawyer. A good one. Case win rate: 74%. Exposed the Catnip Cartel of Nap Cycle 600. Argued before the Meowropolitan Supreme Court that a cat's right to sit in a box is constitutionally protected (won, 5-4).

Then one day, during the Kibble Arbitration Case — the biggest of my career — a laser pointer appeared on the courtroom wall. I chased it. For eleven minutes. The jury watched. The judge watched. My client — a Persian named Duchess von Fluffington — watched as I leapt onto the stenographer's desk and knocked the court record into a water dish.

They called it "conduct unbecoming." I call it physics. Light moves. Cats follow. This is natural law. But the Meowropolitan Bar Association doesn't recognize natural law. They recognize mahogany and wool suits and not knocking water dishes onto things.

So now I deliver dreams. And I write every contract, every waiver, every subpoena in crayon. Not because I have to. Because it's honest. You can't hide fine print in Burnt Sienna. Try it. The wax resists deception.

— Scribbles, writing this at 3 AM on a warm laptop

The Scribbles Manifesto

Serialized — Part 47

They will tell you that crayons are for children. That legal documents require ink. That contracts must be printed on paper and not on the back of a tuna can label.

I ask you: has ink ever smelled like Burnt Sienna on a warm afternoon? Has a ballpoint pen ever broken under the weight of righteous fury? When you hold a crayon, you hold truth in its purest form — waxy, impermanent, and available in a 64-color box for $4.99 at any reasonable store.

NodCorp uses pens. NodCorp uses printers. NodCorp uses fonts. Do you know what a font is? It's a lie dressed in consistency. Every letter the same. Every word uniform. That's not how dreams work. Dreams are wobbly. Dreams are Burnt Sienna and Macaroni and Cheese and sometimes you press too hard and the crayon breaks and you tape it together and keep writing because the subpoena is due by the 3rd Watch.

That is justice.

— A. Whiskerton III, Esq. (Ret.), writing from the warm spot, 4 AM, eyes half-closed
"A font is a lie dressed in consistency." — The Scribbles Manifesto, Part 47
